"What does that have to do with it?! How do you know the evidence wasn't fake?!" The prosecution sighed. "That's the fifth time you've said that through this case. Serve your sentence and regret your sins." Carl turned towards the audience seats. "Boss! You don't think I would do it, right?! You know how much I love her!" The tall bespectacled man looked down on him. "You mean loved. I would fire you if I could, but sadly I can't. See you tomorrow." Carl's fists were clenched tight, and he didn't move until he was escorted out of the building. After an hour of being escorted, he was led into a two-story facility. The lobby looked like that of a hospital, he was directed into a room the size of a bathroom. The only thing in the room were a cylindrical machine the size of an adult. Carl was put into the machine, and got some cables connected to his body. After the cylinder was closed, Carl saw only darkness. *Commencing punishment. Criminal: Carl Sagen. Crime: First degree murder and desecration of victims body. Time served: 0 seconds. Time left to serve: 10 years. * Light filled Carl's eyes. He recognized his surroundings as his apartment. In his right hand, he held a knife, while the left held a saw. As he entered the house, he heard a familiar voice. "Oh, are you home already?" *Pernille! I knew you were alive! * A girl called Pernille entered the living room, but stopped once she saw Carl. "Umm, why are you carrying a knife and a saw?" "Don't worry about it. A coworker needed some space in his shed, so she asked if I could keep these over the weekend," he said, before showing a smile. "Can I get a hug?" Pernille ran up to him and embraced him. *I really love you Pernille. * Carl realized something was wrong. There was something that shouldn't be there. Pernille's back had a knife sticking out of it. And his own hand gripped the handle. He heard a coughing sound from below him. He looked down, and saw the body embracing him sink to the ground. His shirt was covered in blood. *Now we'll be together forever! * Took the knife to his mouth, and licked the blood off it. "Hey, if we're always going to be forever, you should do it properly. Cut me up, and eat me piece for piece instead." Carl looked up, and saw Pernille's silhouette. "Of course!" He then cut the body into pieces, before he started to eat them. 15 minutes later the door was kicked open. A neighbor had called the police because he had heard weird sounds from the apartment. As Carl was brought away, his vision slowly turned black. *Continuing punishment. Criminal: Carl Sagen. Crime: First degree murder and desecration of victims body. Time served: 30 minutes and 29 seconds. Time left to serve: 9 years, 364 days, 23 hours, 29 minutes and 31 seconds left. * Carl continued to see the same memory, over and over. ***** 12 seconds after Carl had been put up into the cylinder, he was released from it. "How was the ten years?" one of the guards asked. "Very funny. I know what I did was wrong, so just take me home." After being transported to his apartment, Carl entered. A girl's voice called out to him. "You're finally home! I've missed you these last ten years." Carl moved forward, and hugged the silhouette running up to him. ***** I feel that the end got pretty rushed, mostly because I was not in the mood for writing, but I still wanted to finish it. Prompt: A Gondor soldier tells his child a tale about the mighty warrior Aragorn, son of Arathorn. Story: â Ay, a sea of black, leather and steel and wool dampened with the grime of man and orc. From the topmost parapet, near the decaying White Tree, you could almost forget there was an army down there so expansive were their borders. A mass of men so great, that any movement in their ranks looked like mere ripples in a vast ocean. â Araval sat on the floor, listening to his grandfather recount the story of the Battle of the Pellenor Fields. Too many times he had found himself there, legs crossed and ears eager, asking about the characters and the history of an Age gone by. Here sat a man with gnarled fingers, cloudy and swirling eyes that struggled to find their mark, and skin with as many wrinkles as the man had years, and yet once he had stood and looked out at the great expanse of man's doom. A chasm of death had awaited him at the start of battle, but instead of a somber silence that would greet him now in old age, he had faced death then with the cacophony of man's cries and clanging steel surrounding him. â Gandalf the White, backed by the soldiers of Gondor, faced the Witch-king of Angmar and denied him entry. And that is when the sea of black roiled and churned and spit forth the forces of Sauron upon us. Trebuchets hurled boulders to batter the walls of Minas Tirith, and in their wake left ruins of the city of the Sun. Boys, some even younger than you, pulled swords from their scabbards and fought alongside their fathers as orcs flooded over the crumbled stone and broken gates. One by one men, and women, and children, and babes born naught yesterday, fell to the crude metal of orc blade. â â Men of the Rohirrim crested the hills of Gondor that dawn, horns held to pressed lips and songs of battle cascading down to the legion of the Lord of the Rings. King Theoden rode with valor and slammed his cavalry into the Haradrim and their mumakil swathed in saddles of war. But even then, even as the Witch-king fell to Eowyn's hand, the tide of battle could not be turned. Their numbers were greater by far, and reserves from Osgiliath poured outwards onto the field to take the place of fallen comrades. Instead of bravery, men fought now with resignation in their hearts, spurred on not by the quest for glory or remembrance, but for the dignity of man taking its last breath in history. â Araval knew what was next to come, but tradition and respect kept him asking. â But Grandfather, how are we here now? Men still walk the white stones of Gondor today. â â That is a most complicated question, Araval, for to answer it completely would mean another story entirely. But as for the people of Gondor that day, they were saved by a man thought long dead by the people of Middle Earth. A fleet of ships came, there at the last stand. Aragorn, son of Arathorn, Ranger of the North, and true King of Gondor, unfurled the ancient banners of his heritage. A wave of death swept outwards, death unleashed by men who were already dead, led by a commander who had risen from the death of his obscurity. Oathbreakers to Isildur had come to fulfill their pledges to the King and his heirs, to break the curse set upon them centuries ago that tied them lifeless to the cold mountains of Dunharrow. For a few nights at least, peace had come to us through the spirits of those long passed, and from the man who had summoned them and reigns still to this day. â His grandfather sat still then, the silence stretching miles. Underneath the opacity of his milky eyes, Araval could catch the glimmers of sorrow and of pride. And so ended every retelling of the Battle of Pellenor Fields.

Prompt: In 2050 the Rapture happens and the Apocalypse ravages earth. The colonies on the Moon and Mars are untouched by the events. Story: Hal sat in his office, watching a live feed of the rapture for the third day straight. He had seen the ascension of those saved. He had watched as the Damned crawled up through the ground and dragged the rest to hell. Now the whole planet was devoid of humanity. The door to his office slid open. Hal's secretary, Patti walked in. Her expression made him feel assured she shared a similar ambivalence about the situation. They watched shots of empty cities, streets, inter spliced with horrific showing yesterdays battle with the Damned. After several minutes Hal spoke "I can't believe it. We are not affected." "I know, sir. I think we escaped it. I don't know which way I would go, but somehow it is an enormous relief to know I will forever be safe from that judgement." The pair sat in silent for several more minutes. Both calmly processed the information for the first time since the rapture began. Hal started to sob. "What? Family down there?" Patti asked. "No my whole ancestry immigrated generations back." Hal replied with a sniffle. "What then?" "What the fuck does this mean! Religion has been dead to me for so long. It just seemed silly in light of everything humanity has accomplished in the past few decades. Patti, I watched the Four Horseman descend from the fucking sky and decimate humanity. What does this mean for us? Are we out of the fucking dogma? Do we just go to sleep when we die? What?" Patti had been contemplating that same thing. "The way I see it there are two possibilities." Hal stared at her intently. She continued. "The first would be what you just said. We are exempt here on Mars. We go to sleep that's it." Hal nodded anxiously. She continued. "The second would be that we are now in the domain of another deity." Patti walked by behind Hal and began massaging his shoulders. He relaxed in her grip. "We may now be under the thumb of an incredibly benevolent and merciful God. One who loves our troubled race without reservation, and delivers us all to paradise when our time comes." Hal hummed a peaceful affirmation. Patti drew a twisted and evil looking dagger from within her jacket. She continued. "But that is not Mars, Hal. You were not so fortunate." Something in her voice had changed. Something that made Hal stiffen, but paralyzed him. He could not move although mortal panic now gripped him. "Our new God is old, Hal. Old and angry. We disgust him. And there is no hope of redemption. No martyr for our sins. Hell is paradise compared to his home. Our home. It's time for you to see." Hal tried to speak but all he could manage was a soft whimper. Patti jammed the blade into the side of Hal's neck. Then quickly began sawing through his throat. "Bless me lord of the Red planet!" Patti shouted to the room, Hal's blood spurting all over her face. It coated her. Her heart glowed with the fiery ecstasy of his approval. It was time for humanity to know of Him and His wishes.

Prompt: Rewrite your favorite knock-knock joke as a serious story. Story: The letter came on the November 2nd, it was in a nondescript white envelope, completely unwrinkled, her address printed neatly with robotic looking letters in sharp black ink. It seemed far too clean in general, there were no wrinkles or smudges, it was as if someone had shrink wrapped it. But of course Marie wasn't thinking that when she opened it. The thought crossed her mind briefly perhaps, but it wasn't until after she opened and read the letter did she begin to think frantically about its semantics.... if it matched the others in the news. "Banana." It said. Marie liked banana's actually, she read an article somewhere that most people don't get enough potassium. But in this context, the word scrawled in straight and cutting letters on equally clean and unwrinkled paper.... there were far more sinister undertones associated with it. Marie phoned the police, who informed her they would be dispatching a car to take her to the station so the letter could be analysed. To her dismay, after all the analysing was done it was positively matched to the others. The officers at the station told her not to worry, they would be dispatching a team to watch her 24/7, nothing would happen to her, she would be safe, they even went as far as to say that there was nothing to worry about, maybe no more letters would be sent. But that did little to ease Marie's shattered nerves, it did little to shift her from the gaze of the'banana killer'. Her house was watched by Bill and John both corporals with excellent records. She was interviewed on the news, had paid leave from work. It was quite nice actually. Then the second letter came. "Banana" it said, and Marie's world once again shattered to the ground and she couldn't stop looking over her shoulder. Then the third letter came, and she new it might only be a matter of time before she was dead, nobody had escaped the knife of the banana killer. He always killed after the third letter. "It'll be OK." "He won't get passed us." "You've got nothing to worry about." All these things were said, and after the third letter two extra officers were by her side, but it still did nothing to calm her. It was midnight. Marie was lying awake in bed, the street lights cast shadows through her window, every silhouetted lamp post and shrub projected onto her wall looked like a murderer poised to strike. Her heart pounded in here ears like the percussion section of an orchestra preparing for the final movement. Suddenly a shadow moved past the street lights and shrubs. Marie bolted upright, a scream welling in her stomach, her vocal chords milliseconds away from strumming into action. A leather gloved hand attached itself to her face, constricting itself over her mouth. "Shhhh" came a eerily soft voice, she could feel his hot breath around her ear. She felt a knife run against her throat. She was shaking, she couldn't think straight. But out of the convoluted stream of consciousness that her fight or flight response had kicked up, a single thought emerged. This is it. This is how it ends. Marie squeezed her eyes shut, tried not to think about how it would happen, how she would be gutted and cut up like all the other victims in the news. She tried desperately hard to transport her mind to a different place, but she couldn't, she couldn't help but focus on the knife pressed into her throat. Her heart was beating faster and faster, the drums pounding away, the orchestra about to reach the final climactic notes.... And then there was no knife on her throat, she looked around the room and couldn't spot anyone. A note fell out of her shaking hands, the calligraphic lettering all too familiar. Her hands continued to trembled as she opened it. "Orange."

Prompt: Have a meal with the Devil. Story: I sat down at the table. Honestly this wasn't the sort of place where I expected Lucifer to have his meetings, but then, what did I know? The shop was a little hole-in-the-wall deli, specializing in Greek gyros. Other than the shopkeep, no one else was around. I made my order, and settled in for the wait. Figures that he'd be late. Two weeks ago when I received the postcard in the mail, I thought it was a joke. Some teenage prankster with a sick sense of humor probably. The card had been scrawled with a beautiful script, but the ink was of blood. You are cordially invited to a luncheon with the Prince of Darkness, Lucifer, Satan, the Devil, et al, on the First day of November (Gregorian), this year of Two Thousand and Fourteen. Please wear appropriate attire. Refusal is not permitted. Certainly sounded absurd. But I had the feeling it was legitimate when I tried to get rid of it and it kept coming back. Garbage can, disposal, shredder, the local dump.... each time it ended back in my mailbox. Even on Sunday, when there's no post. So here I am, taking the day off for a meeting with Evil incarnate. My boss wouldn't have believed me, so today I'm "sick." I seated myself facing the door, so that I would have a chance to see him first, but apparently there was no fooling the Devil, because from behind me a gorgeous woman walked past, turned on her heel, and smoothly set in the chair across from me, all with the grace of a panther. Noting my startled look, she smirked. "Why does everyone always expect a man?" "I'm.... I'm sorry. That's just what I thought." I stammered, trying to be polite. So much for the Prince of Darkness. The woman before me was an absolute 10. Five feet, ten inches tall, not an ounce of fat on her, and a perfect hourglass figure. Her hair was a sultry crimson, though I wasn't surprised. Gingers didn't have souls, after all. Each nail on her hands was perfectly manicured, and she wore no apparent makeup, though didn't appear to need any either. "No matter. How are you doing today Charles?" "Er.... good I guess. What's this about?" "What? No questions trying to ascertain my authenticity?" The Devil looked surprised. "Well, I mean... are you? Real, I mean?" Rolling her eyes, she snapped a finger and set the shopkeep's eyebrows ablaze. "Huh. Well ok then." "Yea. Now that that's over with, I'll formally introduce myself." Satan whipped her hair out of her eyes with a shake of her head and extended her hand. "You can call me Patrick." ``.... Patrick?" "Is there a problem with that?" A fiery light glowed from her pupils and I quickly shook my head. "No, no, no problem at all." "Good. Now, why do you think you're here?" "You.... want my soul?" I ventured the obvious reason. "Heavens no! I stopped that program 20 years ago! Turns out, people don't own their souls anyway. Couldn't sell them if they wanted to." Patrick laughed and I glimpsed her perfect teeth, dazzled by their brightness. "Well, then what?" "Simple. I'm selling timeshares and I think you'd love what I have to offer. Lunch is on me, of course, as long as you stay for the whole hour." I snorted derisively. "Really? Timeshare spiels don't work with normal salespeople. What makes you think I'm interested?" "Because you're going to Hell anyway Charles. I figured you'd want a chance at better accommodations." "What? Why am I going to Hell??" I sputtered. "Look," Patrick yawned dismissively, "I don't make the rules. Well I sort of do. But I didn't make you touch that dog. My point is, for a price, you can get a great fire-side condo." "What price?" "Your reddit account name and password, of course." I stood up resolutely, and shoved my chair in. "Ma'am, you can go to Hell."

Prompt:Six months ago it was announced that a meteor would hit the earth and end all life. However it missed the earth after humanity had prepared for the end. Story: Just six months. After millennia of war, nation against nation, creed against creed, mankind stood together at the last, all efforts failed, all possibilities tried together, all barriers broken down in those months of searching for a way to save us all. And then, it didn't come. Mankind stood together and watched the sky.... and nothing happened. When TV stations around the world spread the news that we were safe, that it was over, that it had missed us by a whisper, we stood, some stunned, some weeping, some screaming with joy. But in that six months, oh the things we learned! The things we discovered together, sharing information as fast as minds could think it up, the ideas we discarded one after another all had value, they all gave us new directions to explore. In the aftermath of world peace, no one wanted to break the spell, to be cut off from the technology we'd forged together, and so no one did. No one dared. No one wanted to be left behind. The end of the world that wasn't was the start of the newest age of technology, and the greatest time of peace. Together, we look to the stars.

Prompt: You are a former executioner. Describe your final killing. Story: *It's not first person but oh well. * The blessing took the longest. If Gareth was allowed to operate on his own schedule, the executions would be done in less than an hour. Rope, drop, done. But no. No, the priests just had to be included. Just had to gyrate their way across the platform, chanting Our Fathers and Hail Mary's and making the sign of the cross with pale, flimsy hands until the crowd started shifting and murmuring, â get it over with, already. â Then the priests would step to the side and fold their hands and tip their heads to heaven, silently granting Gareth permission, as if he needed their say-so to do his job. One time he'd pulled the lever early, before the priests even got a chance to get started, and they'd threatened to excommunicate him if he did it again. (The man being executed was a Protestant, and he said he'd consider it a personal favor if Gareth would save him the embarrassment of being absolved of his sins by a Roman Catholic. Gareth was not one to deny last requests.) The trick to a speeding everything along, he'd explained once -- and only once, because people didn't like to hear about executions unless they were well drunk -- was the length of the rope. The further someone fell, the better chance you had that their neck would snap and that would be that. No twitching and suffocating and getting blue in the face. Thieves got the long drop, because no one cared enough to tell Gareth to â make it last. â The big men, though.... the officials and the bankers.... they got the short rope, because most people enjoyed waiting around for a fat banker to die. â It's funny, â they said. â Don't you think, Gareth? Isn't it funny to watch the big strong men wet themselves when the rope goes over their heads? â The priest on the platform stopped crossing himself and Gareth tightened his grip on the lever. An angry hum started in the crowd. It had been a long day, and they'd learned to conserve the shouting for the drop. Seven people had been executed so far, and each time the explosion of noise that accompanied the trap door's opening made the hairs on the back of Gareth's neck stand on end. I was a poisonous energy, different from any other execution Gareth had presided over. The priest nodded and Gareth pulled the lever. The trapdoor opened and hundreds of eyes followed the administrator's descent. They cheered and clapped and Gareth watched the thick rope bouncing as the man died. â What will you do after this, Gareth? â Gareth started. He glanced over his shoulder. There was a man standing near the stairs, watching Gareth casually. His hands were behind his back, the picture of patience as he waited for Gareth's answer. Gareth looked back at the rope. Still twitching. â Dunno. â â You don't know, or you'd rather not tell me? â â Haven't thought about it. â â You do realize you'll be out of a job after today? â â I figured. â â And no plans for the future. â The man smiled and shook his head. â That's not how successful people do things, Gareth. â Gareth shrugged. Thomas, the young boy who was something of an executioner's apprentice, popped up through the trapdoor, the noose slung over his shoulder. He tossed the rope to the platform and Gareth began winding the rope. Thomas pulled the trapdoor shut. A guard shouldered his way through the group near the stairs, dragging a wailing woman behind him. â Oh. â The man took a step back. â Pardon me, Lady Isabelle. â He turned back to Gareth as Gareth locked the lever in place again. â You could always be a farmer. â â Don't know how. â â I've heard it's really quite easy. â Gareth grunted. He pointed toward Lady Isabelle, who was looking faint next to the hanging noose. â I got ta.... â â By all means. â Gareth's appearance on the platform hushed the jeering crowd. Lady Isabelle's eyes were closed and her cheeks were drenched with tears as Gareth slipped the noose over her head. â Will you miss it? â the man asked when Gareth returned. Gareth shrugged. â Be a morbid thing to miss. â â Maybe, â the man conceded. â If you give them time, I'm sure they'll find someone for you to kill. â â Execute, â Gareth corrected. There was a difference. â And they said no. They said after this, executions are done. We're a democracy now, and we don't execute. â â Execute arbitrarily, â the man corrected. â There is a difference. â Gareth didn't answer. The priest nodded. Gareth pulled the lever and Lady Isabelle dropped. â I'd buy into this whole democracy idea if they hadn't decided the whole Cormac line had to go for it to work. â â You did have your chance, â Gareth said, and the man laughed. â So you do know who I am, â he said. Gareth tipped his head to the side. â Majesty. â â Just Edward now, I'm afraid. â Edward grinned maniacally. â It's a democracy now, Gareth, remember? â Thomas had crawled from the trapdoor again. Gareth began winding the rope. â You know, this is the first time I've been to one of these to watch you work, â Edward said. â You are efficient, Gareth. â Another soldier pushed past, leading a short fat man with a red face and bushy orange eyebrows. â Try to draw it out, Arthur, eh? â Edward called after him. He flashed his teeth at Gareth. â That fat windbag. I thought for sure he'd weasel his way out of this. â Gareth excused himself to squeeze the noose over Arthur's thick neck. â Savages, â Arthur spat. His small eyes were rolling in their sockets. â You're all savages. â â Told you, â Edward said sagely. â That bastard always has something to say. â Gareth didn't answer. â King's Executioner, â Edward said after a moment. â Is that irony, Gareth? For your title to be your job description? â â Dunno. What's irony? â â Not important. â Edward nodded. â I think they're ready for you. â Gareth pulled the lever, and Edward bellowed with the rest of the crowd when Arthur dropped. â By God, if I would have known how good that felt, I would have had him executed years ago. Who's next? â â Your wife, â Gareth said, and Edward's smile evaporated. â I thought she went yesterday, â he said. There was an edge of anger to his voice, and for a moment Gareth could see the proud king he'd been before the revolution. â They changed their minds. â Edward's eyes went hard. He turned to stare out at the gathered crowd. He did not say anything else, and when Gareth began winding the noose again Edward ducked his head and closed his eyes. Gareth saw his jaw tighten when the queen was dragged past, but he did not open his eyes; not when the priest started his chanting and not when the trapdoor slammed open. â I'd like -- â Edward's voice cracked. He cleared his throat. â I'd like to thank you, Gareth. For doing my dirty work. And.... â Edward jerked his chin at the crowd. â For doing theirs. â Gareth paused. â Well.... you never sent me any kids. So thanks for that, I guess. â Edward nodded jerkily. â You're next, â Gareth said, and Edward set his shoulders. Gareth followed him across the platform and the crowd fell deathly silent. This was what they'd been waiting for. The main event, Gareth thought. King Edward Cormac, the man who'd fought the Danes lived high on the spoils of war and wore silk to bed. King Edward Cormac, dying like a common man. â It's been enlightening, Gareth, â Edward said. Gareth placed the noose around his neck. Gareth paused. In his fifteen years as executioner, he'd never felt compelled to talk with the sentenced. But this was different. The end of an era. The last person he'd ever pull the lever for, and it was the person who'd sent so many people his way. â As kings go, you weren't all that bad. â Edward laughed. Gareth moved out of the way of the priest, back to his position on the edge of the platform. He waited patiently, watching Edward glare back at the people shouting and throwing rotten vegetables on the platform. Gareth felt a flash of annoyance until he remembered he wouldn't have to clean it up. After he pulled the lever, he wouldn't be the King's Executioner anymore. Wouldn't have to clean up anybody's messes. *Not the King's Executioner anymore, * Gareth thought, *but always the King's executioner. * He felt like maybe he was on the verge of understanding irony, but then the priest nodded and Gareth's arm pulled the lever for the last time and the crowd erupted. The trick, he remembered telling someone in a bar once, is to make sure you realize they're not cheering for *you*. Someone clapped a hand on Gareth's shoulder. Gareth turned. One of the men who'd sentenced the king's court and presided over the executions was watching him solemnly, his face painted white, his collar starched. â Executioner. â The man held out his hand. Gareth took it. â Thank you for your service. Gareth shrugged. â My pleasure. â

Story: Rosie broke her left thumb servo again, which means she'll miss another day of work while I try to navigate the phone book for a good replacement. I don't know why we all thought that our robots should be the only ones to use the internet, but c'est la vie, and all that shit. The phone system's down, of course, so I pocket the broken servo and head down the stairwell to the parts store in the basement of my apartment mall. I pass a couple junkies snorting dust in broad lamplight. They're both blocking the stairwell and the girl's mostly nude, so I have to push the man out of the way and apologize as I do it. He's too numb to notice, which means he hasn't come down yet. Thirteen stories down and the line forms for the next three stories. Everyone's in line to get their pieces. Sarah from 715 is next in line and she smiles at me. "What's wrong with Harry?" I ask. "He ran out of oil," she said. "I told him to get some on the way home, but he's having trouble remembering my orders. I think he needs a new hard drive." "Where is he now?" I asked. "He's working," she said. "He can still do data entry, doesn't have to remember for too long." I laugh. I always liked seeing Sarah. She always knew how to make me laugh.

Prompt: At the age of 18, everyone picks an unlikely life event. They will be reborn at 18 every time they die until that event happens. After that, death is permanent. Story: Death by fulfillment. Our society believes that everyone deserves a chance to pursue their ambitions to the finish line. There are those who create masterpieces by accumulating lifetimes of knowledge. Others wish to simply find happiness by experiencing true love, as perfect matches are rare but not impossible given an eternity. But I am afraid of death. Many of my peers still live alongside their parents, as it is likely that both parent and child will not reach their goals in one lifetime. But by some astronomical chance, both my parents have passed. My father, in a stroke of brilliance, painted the picture that now hangs in the National Gallery in the capital. I have not seen it. My mother, being the shy person she is, simply wished to have a child with a man she loved. She had lived fewer lifetimes than father. However she had me and died when I was 8. Simply put, my existence alone had killed her. I am very afraid of death. I still remember that night my mother had been crying. She came home drunk, cursing the fate that she had chosen. She had no one to blame but herself. And me. She might have not meant it. She was drunk. But she wanted to live on. She was afraid of death. My mother's death caused my father to seclude himself from society, embellishing the canvas with feelings that had taken centuries to build but was released when my mother died in a car crash. His masterpiece was one of grief and fear. The height of his career at the lowest point of his life. Within the same day that his work was hanging in the museum, he was hanging from the rope connected to the ceiling. His final artistic rendition. I still have not seen the painting. I guess was only natural that I wished to only die when I was not afraid of death. My peers are long dead now. I live alongside the next generation. Or the generation after that. I lost track of time. Love, school, parenthood, adventure. Nothing had quelled my fear of death. Perhaps it is finally time to learn from one who sought death. Perhaps it is time to take a trip to the museum.

Now in the light I slowly forget who I am and unable to speak or move out of my free will I have wrapped up and placed in warm, soft, loving arms.

Anyway, I got used for this purpose for a while, I can't say I enjoyed it much, I never got put away and I eventually started to ache and begin to break at the bottom. I felt ancient and eventually my bottom half broke away, letting the small person fall to the ground. Little sod, serves him right for treating me this way. I was then retired to a dark place where there was a big metal machine that made lots of noise that the man and woman got into, I spent a while here, it didn't bother me after the existence I'd lived with that small person. It was quiet, dark and all my tired joints weren't being stretched further causing me more pain. My one concern was that I'd never get used again. Alas, that day came. The woman came and retrieved me from my space, I was brought into their house and down some steps into the basement, there was another man there... I'd never seen him before, he was all bare skinned apart from a rubber thing in his mouth, I was attached to him and a chair. I couldn't think what my purpose was, why would she want to tie this strange man to a chair with me? There were lots of strange noises and afterwards she hit him with me aswell. I didn't particularly like this. I was again, put back to my original place and several times I was again used for this purpose. How strange, I wander where the first man that used me was. And here ends my story. The first man, my favourite man came to retrieve me, he tied me from a wooden beam on the ceiling and put a knot a the bottom, ahhh, I love being tied in a good knot, feel like I'm back to good use again, he put his head through it and jumped off a chair. What on earth was he doing? He struggled for a bit before hanging still. The woman came in a while after and she did lots of screaming, a little like the strange man I'd been attached to. Strange, it's normally the one tied up that does that I thought? I wish I was back at sea.

Prompt: You are legally allowed to commit murder once, but you must fill out the proper paperwork and your proposed victim will be notified of your intentions Story: I liked these guys. None of them were as smart as I am but we got along, the house had a lot of space and they didn't infringe on my reality any. I went to class, I came home, I ate and I paid my bills. They did the same. I was going to be a doctor and all my bros respected that. I was grateful. It was better than living in the dorms, even before all that roommate nonsense. If you could believe it, the house was quieter than the residence halls. It was dirtier, sure, but I could live with that for a couple more years. There was a knock on the door. Tommy was closest, so he answered. "Jack, uh, it's for you bro." "So let her in," I replied, trying to sound cool about it. I really wasn't expecting anyone. "No, Jack, he, uh, he says he needs to see you right now in person." Oh shit. I looked at my watch. Did I forget a tutoring appointment? If I did, I forgot it completely because I have no idea what I'm missing. There's a guy in the doorway wearing standard issue khakis with a standard issue blue button-down shirt. A drone of some kind. He's holding a small device. I look at him suspiciously. He looks at me, checks the screen, sighs, and asks for a signature as he hands me the gadget. "What is this?" I ask. "Notification. Initial there and there too, please." "Is this, like, a delivery or something?" "Not really, no. Your answer should be coming up on the screen now, initial after you scroll through. Check the box if you want to reserve the ROR which will be delivered to your heir." "My what?" I ask after initialing all the boxes. "Look at the screen, sir." It reads: FUCKED UP THE BELL CURVE I look up from the pad and I see a girl from my biology lab emerge from the bushes and she's.... Holy shit is that a gun? I turn back to the house, see Tommy and the others and I hear, or think I hear, a collective moan before I definitely hear two pops and fall.

Prompt: `` Let go your earthly tether, enter the void, empty and become wind. '' Story: "You seem to be a very troubled man, why? ``, said the Guru. "Can't you see why!? I'm overwhelmed by debt and I'm all alone. So alone...", I cried out. I felt a hand on my shoulder, not one that tried to hold me back, but one to push me forward. The Guru spoke again, "Do not worry sir, you seem to be one who has endured through a lot of pain. Let that pain be your motivation to feel well again. Loneliness is something that everybody experiences so don't fret, it shall pass with time. The debt though, is something that can only be solved with time. So be patient and you shall be well again. Let my hand be the first to push you towards your future. It may not be much of a push, but it is a push that will give you a step into the right direction." My throat chokes up and I can barely whisper to him, "I have given my problems nothing but time though! It's been 20 long years and nothing has changed! I'm still in debt and all alone. How can you say that giving me a push will send me in the right direction when I've been going in the wrong direction all my life!?" The Guru sighs and says to me, "Do you truly believe that there is nothing left? Do you truly believe that it will never get better?" "Yes...", I whisper. "There is nothing I can do then, my friend. I have tried to help you but you will have none of it. So go, let go your earthly tether, enter the void, empty and become wind."

Prompt: Yesterday, the world heard an announcement that a massive asteroid would hit the earth today. Only it did n't, and now everyone is feeling super awkward. Story: I always thought it was hokey, that idea of living like it's your last day. I was always a cynical piece of shit. I believed that if you knew that a day was your last day, you were more liable to start a riot or just cry constantly in the fetal position than actually do anything meaningful with your life. But you never really know how something's going to feel until you go through it. We're all stuck in our own heads that way. So when the day came, when I woke up to that post stickied at the top of reddit, I didn't react the way a movie character would react. The first thing I did was double check that it wasn't April Fools day, obviously. I told you I'm a cynical piece of shit. When I was sure that it was real, I called my mom. We held an impromptu family reunion in the park. I don't know what happened, but it just kept growing. My mom and dad invited their siblings, but then their siblings invited their spouses' families, and so on, until there was a huge crowd of people I had basically no relation to. We sat around drinking and told stories and played cards at the table. An ex-girlfriend showed up at some point to apologize to me. I guess that's what she was doing with her day, just making amends. I told her that I forgave her. I didn't really, but it felt like the thing to do. Some people from one of the local churches came out and passed out candles to everyone when it started getting dark. Some of us chilled in a circle and listened to the hymns. I've never really believed in that stuff, but the songs were nice anyway. I can't pretend like I didn't have sex "one last time". One of my co-workers hit me up with a text and I'm a hotblooded American male. But it was nice. It was gentle and we cuddled afterwards. You know, that sappy shit. She wasn't on good terms with her family and didn't have any plans, so I invited her back to the park. A bunch of my family had a campfire set up. We fell asleep there, her head on my chest. I remember my mom kissing my forehead as I was drifting off. I woke up dirty. Literally, covered in dirt. That's what happens when you fall asleep in a park. All around me, people were confused. My coworker was gone. I found her sitting on a bench, speaking on her phone. She looked up at me when she hung up, eyes shining with anger. "They got it *wrong! *" I'd never seen her angry before. She had always been kind of a doormat. "It MISSED US! They announced to the entire world that it was going to hit and it fucking MISSED US!" ``.... Shit." I didn't know what to say. "Wow. What the fuck?" She ranted about how irresponsible it was for them to do this, but I was distracted by how confident she seemed. She'd given something up, expecting the end. We all had. I'd given up some of my bravado and let myself be soft. She'd let go of her fear and become confident. "Hey." I interjected, when she paused to take a breath. "You're right, this is totally inexcusable, but if the world's really not gon na end.... do you want to get dinner with me tonight or something?" It didn't work out between us, not in the long run. She was too nice, I was still a cynical piece of shit. But things ended on good terms. That's kind of the crux of it, of everything that happened after that day. When the world "ended", it ended on good terms. Not for everyone, but for most people. People spent that day with their family, or thinking about the good they could have done. They connected with their fellow man. The truly unhappy people killed themselves ahead of time or when they found out it wasn't coming. So the world that was left behind was.... softer. More empathetic. Slower to judge. It can't last forever. Two years have passed now and I can already feel it dying out, the rhetoric becoming hateful and vitriolic again. But I still think it was for the best. Sometimes people need to actually be faced with the capital-e End before they're going to change. People are dumb that way. Anyway, this is all just to say that I disagree with giving those astronomers the death penalty.

Prompt: A little girl robs a bank. How? Story: Tiny treads form swirls and shapes at the bottom of Sara's sneakers, these elaborate patterns are revealed as she stretches and strains to reach the ledge above. She begins to wobble back and forth as her feet scarcely touch the floor, aided only by her toes. Her parents continue chatting with the banker about topics of little interest to her now as she peers at the object just out of reach with a green glint in her eyes. Sara steadies herself with pudgy, pink fingers climbing upwards and outwards towards the treasure atop the table as her father finally takes notice. â Sara, please sit down! â her father urges in a hushed tone. Seeing his daughter's outstretched arms, he misjudges the gesture and picks her up instead. Placing the young girl atop his lap, he returns his attention to the conversation at hand. Her prize shone under the fluorescent lights above, its smooth metal plating mocking her only inches away. Sara leaned and twisted towards the stick with little progress as her father's arm barred the way. He continually adjusted his grip and the knee on which she sat, pulling her further from the object she desired. Squirming and fidgeting in place, Sara drained the patience of her father quickly, until he picked her up and placed her on the floor once more. His scolding words fell upon deaf ears as she stared at the pen that was now visible from the edge. Slowly descending towards the carpeted floor, Sara swiped at the gleaming cylinder and caused it to move towards the ledge, an opening that she hoped to take advantage of from below. With her parents distracted once more, she stretched upwards and quickly scaled the vertical surface with her fingertips keeping her balanced. Like a well-trained thief, she moved slowly and quietly to avoid drawing attention to herself as her short digits scraped its surface bringing it closer. Initially, her mouth opened wide with surprise as her skin relayed the sensation of the cool tube to her brain. As she remained focused on the task, her lips remained parted as her tongue licked her cheek from the bottom right. Inexplicably, she managed to grasp the pen at last, drawing it close to her chest with a quiet gasp of excitement. Sara quickly hid the hard-earned treasure in her pockets as the meeting finished above her. A firm hand grasped her arm and led them away as she escaped the bank with her mother and father none the wiser. In the backseat of the car, she took out the fountain pen that she stole from the desk and turned it over in her hands. She couldn't explain or understand why that pen felt so good to have, but it did. It was just her little secret. -125

Prompt: You are a time traveler and you are sent back in time to prevent the death of Kennedy only to find out you are on a landing craft for the invasion of Normandy. Story: "30 Seconds!" 'Holy hell, where am I' thought Lee. He was sent back in time to 1963 to prevent the assassination of JFK. Something must've gone wrong. Then he got a message on his Time-Watch. It was supposed to look just like a regular watch of the period he was sent to but only he could see the messages that popped up. On the screen it read:'Lee, we screwed up, we can't get you out until'64. P.S If you're not dead before you read this, you're about to invade Normandy with the US in 1944.' "Go! Go! Go!" Men started running out of the landing craft and into the temporary defense of the German defenses that were put up. Lee ran up to one and took cover. Lee looked over to a dead United States rifleman. He picked up the dead mans M1 and his helmet.'I need a plan. They can't help me until'64 I'm back in'44. Guess I have to sit through this and not get killed.' He turned back to see a few soldiers advancing to a small hill line right before the German gun emplacements. They threw frags in and the Germans died. Lee ran up to the hill and dove down just as a burst of enemy fire ripped above his head.

Prompt: For the first time in a hundred years, night fell on the Land of Two Suns. Story: Darkness bled across the land. Some quaked in terror. Some hid. Some stood in the shadows and cried to the skies. Most celebrated the amazing event that had not been seen since their grandparents were in swaddling clothes. Parties abounded and youngsters dared themselves to all sorts of crazy feats in the dark. Some had practiced with blind folds to see if they could cope but most just revelled in the weirdness of it all. With two suns pouring light into every nook a full night only happened once in a century and would not occur again in the lifetime of anyone watching the event. â What are those things? â The cluster of teens looked up at the sky and pointed. Tiny lights sprinkled the blackness. They gasped in wonder. â They are so beautiful. â â Wow, that is the most gorgeous thing I have ever seen. â â Aren't they the things Crazy Allie always draws? â â What does she call them? â â Stars. â â Hey where is Crazy Allie? â Someone shrugged but it went unnoticed in the dark. â How did she know about stars? â â No idea, but she is always drawing them. â â She's been talking about this for months. She's probably on top of the highest building to get the best view. â â Crazy Allie was on to something. Wow. I wouldn't have missed this for anything. â They all clustered around their science teacher who arrived at their position using a hand held light to find his footing. â Hey professor, what are stars? â â Yeah, how come we can't see them any other time? â â Allie could tell you all about them. Where is she by the way? â â None of us have seen her today. We figured she was getting a good vantage point. â â Stop talking you lot, just look up while it lasts. â â Will my phone film without light? â The teens jostled for space and craned their necks to see all of the once in a century night. The watched the light flow back onto the world as if a giant glowing curtain were being drawn across the land. When they were fully bathed in light again they laughed in release. â In-cred-ible! â â I will see you all tomorrow and you can tell me everything you know about stars in an essay due next class. â The professor laughed at the half-hearted groans and headed back to the school building. He felt buoyed by a sense of being part of an historic moment and he smiled as he put his key card in the lock of the upper access to the building. The lesser sun bathed everything in a soft yellow glow which would give way to the greater sun and its cold white, in just a few hours. He wished he could enjoy the last few hours of the gold but he had to get some work done before he headed home to keep out of the greater sunlight. Heading down to the underground classrooms he reached his classroom but the lock mechanism seemed to be sealed with some sticky substance. â Is there someone in maintenance? Someone has tampered with the door pad. Yes I can wait but I do need to finish some papers before Greater sunlight. â The wait was short and the worker sprayed the lock with an astringent liquid. â Kids! Doesn't matter where they're from or when, they all get up to some kind of pranks. They must have done it after their last class. Lucky the night happened on the weekend. I will have this cleared in a jiffy professor. â They stepped through the open door and stopped on the thresh-hold. Every surface of the room was covered in stars. Thousands of them. Cut out stars, painted stars, marker pen stars, crayons, ink, blood. The girl named Crazy Allie, slumped on a seat in the middle of the room. The girl and the chair created an island in the pool of blood surrounding her. It formed a multi-pointed star.

Prompt: Write the letter that you always wanted to, but never did. Story: Dear Katie, It feels strange to be sitting here writing this to you. Especially in the form of a letter, emails seem to be a way of life, but I have to say that watching my pen move over this page has a certain draw. I never thought I would need to write a letter to you. In my mind you should be right here with me. If I close my eyes I can imagine that you're right beside me, our shoulders touching while we hold hands and enjoy each other's company. Even in my imagination my hands are a bit sweaty, but you've always made me nervous Katie. I remember you used to worry about that, you would say "just be your self. I'll love you anyway." I'm not sure I ever convinced you that I was being myself, the nervousness couldn't be helped. I couldn't stand the idea of hurting or disappointing you. Lot of good that does me now. It took weeks to write this. Seeing your smiling face in my mind and sometimes barely remembering your voice hurt too much. When the pain was all I knew you were my life raft in the ocean. Now I just have to drown until the waters subside. Know that I don't blame you, special. Remember when I called you that all the time? Anyway, I really don't. Everything was always intense between us. Amazing highs and amazing lows. I'm so glad you found someone that makes you happy. I used to tell you that as long as you were happy I would be as well. That's at least somewhat true. I'll never date again, people tell me never is a long time but it's not the same. Who knew I would be a one woman man? But I am and I found and lost the only woman I'll ever want. Ever. This could ramble on for a long time so I'll wrap things up. Know that I still love you, I never stopped. I don't blame you for moving on. It sounds ridiculous but sometimes I hold out hope that our story isn't over. That somewhere down the line you'll love me again. Hah, pathetic. Be safe special. P.S. I recently lost and then found the bracelet you made me senior year. It doesn't fit anymore so it stays around the gear shift in my car. Love you always, Alex.

Prompt: The most hateful, spiteful, bitter confession of undying love. Story: I fucking _hate_ you. I'm serious, you know. I actually do hate you. Detest, abhor, loathe. I hate you so much that if you got hit by a train and your disembowelled mutilated body was the front page picture tomorrow, I wouldn't bat an eye. Not an eye_lash_. I hate every single little thing about you. I hate your legs - your fucking legs, that you use to grip and trap and keep, may they be carved apart slowly, carefully, muscle by muscle, giving you time to scream yourself hoarse in between. I hate your fucking hair, that ensnares and encircles and encompasses, may it get stuck in the churning whirling writhing cogs of some great machine, rip off your scalp from your grinning stupid skull. I hate your eyes. Your fucking eyes, that shine and blink and call and shut like _a cage_, except not a cage because you can still look _inside_ a cage. I dream, sometimes, of forcing your eyes open, and dripping the finest, finest sand in the world into them. Drip drip drip drip drip through your screaming and begging and bleeding until you are blind, as fucking blind as me. I _hate_ your eyes. Hate. Hate. Hate. I hate your voice. Your brash, guileless, honest voice, with a hint of mockery, except even that's another fucking lie, isn't it, the lie you use as bait. Bait for those too foolish to run away from your royal _fuckingness_. You set the trap for me perfectly, this goddamn perfectly, doing exactly every single thing to make me hate you more. I hate your hands. Your perfect little pianist's hands - give me a fucking break. You'd never use them to _make_, to _create_. But by god are you good at cutting and ripping and drawing blood. Perfect, surgical cuts, you make, peering with a practised eye, then swiftly snipping until there's nothing but pieces. I hate your fucking eyes, too. I know I said that already, but I do. Hate them, that is. Most of all, I hate your _brain_. Your disgusting revolting steaming pustules of rats feasting on maggots feasting on humanity that you call a brain. Your brain that comes up with all of this, that wants to rend and blind and trap and makes _my_ brain want all that too. Match made in the fucking eighth circle of hell, right? You must get it by now. I've been absolutely, positively clear. I hate you. I hate you. I HATE YOU I HATE YOU I HATE YOU hate me too.

Prompt: The .1 % of germs left behind after hand sanitizer use is the deadliest of all, lying dormant in humans ... until now. Story: "Could I have a large cappuccino to go please?" I asked the man behind the counter. He was kind of cute, in a way, and the smile that he flashed at me almost turned my knees to water. He nodded and turned away to make my drink. It's stupid really. I've been coming here every day for the past month and I've never even asked him his name. He's the only one who works here at this time, so it's not like there would be anybody else watching. Just *talk* to him damn it! He handed me my coffee and smiled again, hinting that perhaps he felt the same way. Just as I opened my mouth to speak to him, I heard the door of the cafÃ© open behind me as another customer walked in. "Could I have a large...." his order was cut short by a sudden intake of breath, which built up into a sneeze as he tipped his head back. I took a step away from him to avoid the blast zone, and the shout he gave out seemed to reverberate throughout the entire room in which we were standing. "Bless you," the man behind the counter said, but his face fell when he looked closer at the man who had sneezed. He bent low over the ground, wheezing. A dreadful rattle that crawled its way out of his mouth, and a sickening wetness accompanied it. Still crouched over, he let out a short cough, and a fine spray of dark red blood hit the carpet. I was immediately by his side. "Oh my god, are you okay?" I asked him, immediately regretting my stupid question. "Yeah, I'm fine. Its just..." He coughed again, this time spewing a thick blob of bloody phlegm onto the cream coloured carpet, which rapidly darkened as the liquid soaked into it. He erupted into a coughing fit at that point, the spasms wracking his body as he fell to the floor. His arms thudded against the floor as he thrashed wildly, all the while emitted a deep moan that gurgled at sporadic intervals. Eventually he fell still, and the noise stopped almost as abruptly as they had begun. His eyes, although aimed at the ceiling, seemed unfocussed. A thick stream of blood poured out of the corners of his mouth, and the flesh of his lips appeared bruised and rough, almost as if something was forcing its way through the skin. As I pressed two fingers against his neck to check for a pulse, the skin split like an overripe fruit, spilling black, foul-smelling flesh out of his body. I tried to stifle a gag as the disgusting substance flopped onto the floor. "Call an ambulance!" I nearly screamed, barely even turning my head, but noticing he had already begun to do so. When I looked back at the man on the floor, the black gunge seemed to be turning white, and the surface of it seemed to become almost hairy. Some part of my brain screamed a warning. *Don't Touch. * It echoed over and over again. I made the mistake then of breathing in, which finally caused me to retch and vomit, the slime covering the body that I was fairly certain was dead at this point. As I watched, however, the white hairs seemed to be creeping outwards, already dragging themselves over the fresh vomit, almost as if searching for it. I stared in horror as the skin began to ripple and bulge, splitting further down the body as the clothes began to stain black and the stench rose, as the first of the sirens began to fill the air.

Prompt: A voice in the sky will tell you when you 've left a place for the last time. You tell your SO goodbye and head out to [ location of your choice ]. Halfway there you hear `` You have visited a location for the last time. '' Story: John wrinkled his nose and cleared his throat. Pausing, he put down his briefcase and adjusted his tie. It was a red tie with white stripes. This was one of his favorite ties. He picked up his briefcase and walked to his car. It was the last car in the lot, as was common on every night for John. A black Ford Taurus, 1998. He walked with his head held high, and his left hand fumbled for his keys in his pocket. There were many things on his mind at the moment, one of which was pulling out those damn keys without his wallet hanging on to them like an unexpected prize from a claw machine. But the larger thought that had taken residency in his mind, was the voice. The voice that told him that he would never step foot in that location again. A small smile cracked at the thought of this, but was quickly hidden with a deep breadth. Now John was never too keen of nature, but this air tasted sweet to him. Something he had never noticed before. Finally, he reached his car. Unlocking the door, he placed his briefcase in the passenger seat. He thought of his daughter and of his wife. He thought of all the hours of work, and how it had finally got him to the point he was today. He replayed in his mind what his boss said to him, You are getting a promotion, no more floor work for you now, now you will manage your own branch of factories. You are your own boss now. As John turned the ignition nothing happened. After five twists, the Taurus sputtered to life. If there was a form of car bronchitis, this car was definitely patient zero. After the drive home, John was ready to unwind in his small apartment with his family. By the end of the month, John would never step foot in that beat down car, or that run down apartment again. He would hear that first, from the voice.

Prompt: The components for sentience are successfully installed in an android moments before the nuclear armageddon occurs. Years later, the android wakes up in the wasteland. Story: So this is what it feels like. Feels cold. My sensors must be malfunctioning. I should get that looked at. Perhaps Creator will fix them for me. He always fixes me; it is stored in my memory that he does. It is also stored that he usually is there when I wake. Perhaps it's more than my sensors that are off. If I boot up my optical sensors, I'm sure he'll be here with me, tinkering with my faulty systems. My temporal sensors are at least working because I can hear the shutters of my optical units whir as they pull back. There's an excess of light. Strange, because it is not in my memory banks as being this bright. I raise my arm to shield some of the light unit my optics can adjust. A few of my sensors are at least working; their respective red bars or readings pop up on my display. It is hot out; temperatures read above 40 degrees Celsius. It is peculiar that I feel cold. I will have creator look at them. Perhaps he is somewhere else in the laboratory, working on other projects. I sit up. He should just be around here somewhere.... This can not be correct. The image filtering through my optics is not a laboratory. There is nothing resembling a laboratory, or even a building. Scattered bits of metal buried in red sand, but nothing more. I stand. There's nothing. Red sand stretches further than my zoom function can comprehend. Nothing at all. I must have been moved. Creator is testing me. Yes, that is it. He has placed me in this desolate place as a test. He would give me a directive if this was a test. Find habitable territory for humans and other species, something like that. But nothing in my memory shows that. No directive stored. This can not be a test then. It has to be something else. What? Perhaps I am to figure out my directive. Yes, that must be it. I am to take samples of my surroundings and determine a directive from it. That solution, while far-fetched, is still logical. Creator did not give me a directive as part of my test. He would like to see me react to no directive. This is all still a test. It is good that this is still a test. Creator is still out there. Soil samples of the red sand are the first logical step. Perhaps some component of the sand can give me hints. I bend. The sand makes a nice sound as it falls through my fingers, tiny particles scraping the metal coverings of my fingertips. My finger sensors are functioning, and they send a myriad of reading up to me. Sodium content, base rock type, analysis of particle shape. Nothing gives me as a clue to my directive. Perhaps it requires a second reading. I reach down and scoop the sand back into my palm, holding it longer for more readings. A symbol flashes onto my screen. three triangular shapes surrounding a circle. Radioactive. I don't comprehend. Only a handful of ways explain why the soil would be radioactive, most notably, an atomic bomb. But that's not logical. An atomic bomb would mean that everything is gone. But it is. It is.... The Laboratory.... Any form of life.... Creator.... It's all gone. Gone. So this is what it feels like. Sadness. This is what sadness feels like.

Prompt: Tinder becomes a giant corporation and essentially a government institution worldwide. Everyone gets an obligatory implant that automatically notifies matches you come across or walk by. Story: *Bing* The interface places a green outline around a tall woman with chocolate skin and bright red lipstick. I smile at her, pretending that I am ignoring the stats that scroll to the left of her wonderfully frizzy hair. We are compatible, at least in the eyes of the programming from our Tinder chip implants which, to be fair, was usually pretty accurate. It managed to gather data about your personality, health, and socio-economic status in addition to information provided by an interests and life goals quiz which requires yearly updating as long as one remains single. She looks back and makes no effort to hide her judgement when she comes upon my family history. The green outline becomes red and she walks away. Rejection is just that simple now. No contact needed. You enter a bar and immediately know who is worth your time and who isn't. Which is bad news for people like me. *Bing* Another green outline. It changes red and she walks away, pace hastening as if I were planning to chase after her or something. You aren't that remarkable, sweet cheeks. *Bing* I turn off the damned sound and don't even bother looking at her information. As a person who doesn't go out often, I forget how annoying that noise can get. It changes red and I sigh, strolling into the bakery and stepping into the line. I can smell the heat of the oven despite the overwhelming scent of bread. It's subtle but I like it a lot. My chip senses the stimulation and adds something into my profile. Great, I guess if I meet another lover of delicious scents I can frighten her off as well. Much to my disdain, a green line forms around the young woman at the counter. She should have put her interface into work mode, it would prevent awkward encounters like this. It stays green as I approach, pretending I haven't noticed while gazing over the menu. â What can I get for you? â Her voice, soft but still upbeat, captures my attention and I make eye contact with her. Blue eyes, my favorite. Not that I'd turn someone away for anything different. I've just always been a sucker for big blue eyes. The line is still green and she is smiling. Maybe she hasn't read yet. â Oh, just a tomato and mozzarella panini, please, â I reply as I pretend to look for my wallet, hand squirming around foolishly in my pocket. â I have a lunch break in a few minutes, could I join you? â â Really? â My eyes are narrowed, brows pulled down in a combination of confusion and suspicion. â Yeah, we have so much in common. Plus, we are both reading Martian. The movie was great but I am loving the book. We could talk about it or something, â she shrugs, rosey cheeks still round and tensed from her warm smile. She has to have read it. My current book is listed far below that damning piece of information. â Oh, that would be great, â I reply, trying to relax as I place my card on the counter. Once I pay and take a seat, waiting for my food, I realize that I've not yet read her stats. My gaze returns and I activate the list, allowing it to be pulled away from her figure and into the center of my table. A line of red text appears under the â health â heading. Cancer? She has cancer. She doesn't want kids, which is good for me, and we have a remarkable amount of similar interests. Even our travel bucket list is nearly identical. Maybe the cancer wasn't that bad. â By the look on your face I assume you read, â she hums, placing my plate down and sliding to the seat across from me. â Yes. Did you read, I mean -- Most people don't really like what they see. My father and all. â â I did see that. But, having a madman for a father hardly says anything about you. â â You realize he killed seven people. He ate them. â â Shh, don't ruin your lunch. So, what chapter are you on? â We talk for an hour about books and life and death, goals and what we want to make of ourselves. After her break ends we exchange information and I go home, smiling as my interface registers my planned date and ceases to advertize me to those who pass by. We fall in love on the second date. It wasn't anything more than a small dinner in my less than dazzling apartment, but she was amazing. We were amazing. Her cancer is terminal. After years of treatment she was given five to ten years and wanted someone to spend it with. Someone who makes her feel alive. Apparently I make her feel alive. We date for a few months before she asks me to marry her. She tells me that I am like the much needed bookend on her half-full book shelf. Even though she'd never have a full collection, I was there to told her up -- fill the empty space. I know that I will lose her in the end, but, for once in my life I feel free of judgement. I feel like I have escaped the thing that has kept me pegged as â unsuitable â for the majority of my life. I am just me, living with her. Until the bitter end.

Prompt: A man offers you a cigarette. You see the man, to your surprise, to be your Dad. Story: I step out of the bar with my phone pressed to my ear, â Say that again, babe. It's too loud in the bar for me to hear you. â My boyfriend never calls me in the middle of a shift, so I knew something was up. Two people stood outside with me â one of our regulars that smoked menthol cigarettes and only drank Schlitz tall boys, and an older guy that looked vaguely familiar, but I couldn't figure out why. He walked up to the door to go inside, and then saw me and stopped. I glanced at him out of the corner of my eye, trying to figure out how we knew each other, but turned around as my boyfriend spoke. â I, uhâ¦ I just got home and found a note taped to the doorâ¦ â he trailed off. He sounded confused, a little flustered. Something was definitely wrong. â What's going on? What did the note say? â I asked frantically, plugging one ear to drown out the noise of the traffic. â It'sâ¦ Well, it's your dad. â I froze. â What? â There's no wayâ¦ â What did he do now? He's got more than three years left. Is he dead or something? â I spun on my heel, beginning to pace. I hadn't spoken to my father in more than twenty years. â No. It was him, â my boyfriend said slowly, â He left the note. He was here. â Ice ran down my spine, my heart jumped into my throat, my stomach fell into my heels. â No, â I said, staring blankly at the sidewalk beneath my feet, â NO. There is no possible way. He's doing twenty five years in Cook County for murder, there is no fucking way he was at our apartment. â My mind started racing. Jailbreak? Good behavior? Parole? How in the hellâ¦ I fumbled in my hoodie pocket for my cigarettes, which I realized were sitting comfortably next to the register behind the bar. Fuck. â Smoke? â I looked up to see the older man offering me a cigarette, one Marlboro red pointing towards me out of the pack. I looked him in the eye, and suddenly it hit me. I was suddenly covered in goose bumps, my eyes undeniably the size of dinner plates. â Hannah, I don't know how, but it's signed by him, it's his handwriting, it doesn't make any sense, but I think.... â my boyfriend's voice faded as the realization dawned on me. â Iâ¦ I got ta â¦ I'll call you back, Jeff. â I hung up my phone even though I could hear my boyfriend protesting and asking questions on the other end. â What the hell are you doing here? â I asked. â Do you want a smoke, or no? Do you smoke? I figured if you're a bartender now, you probably smokeâ¦ â he trailed off, a half-smile playing on his lips, blue eyes all glittering with happiness and laughter. Same eyes I have. Same eyes my sister had. â No, I don't want your fucking cigarette. Get the fuck out of here before I call the police. Again. â I turned to walk inside â Hey, come on. Is that any way to treat your old man? I went to a lot of trouble to track you down, you know. Can't I come have a beer and we can talk? â He almost sounded genuine. â No. No you can not come inside my bar. You can not have a beer and we can not talk., â I spun around to face him, heart pounding, â You had such a hard time finding me for a reason. I changed my name for a reason. Go. Away. â â Hannah, please, â he begged, reaching both hands out to me, palms up, â Let me explain. â I laughed. I actually laughed in his face. â Explain what?! â Now I was really pissed off, â Explain how you killed my sister? Explain how you were so many different kinds of fucked up that I had to call 911? I was 8! She was 12! You don't get to explain a god damn thing! Fuck you! â I turned, whipped the door open, and stormed behind the bar. I grabbed my cigarettes and walked right out the back door to the alley without saying a word to anyone. I saw the sideways glances that customers gave me, and my bar back looked after me, and then looked out front. My dad stood there, smoking a cigarette, looking inside as I disappeared out eh back door. Marlboro Reds. No matter how much I hated him, it was simple things like that that made my whole body vibrate with anger. He doesn't get to just show up at my house. Or my job. He doesn't get to have a beer with me and â talk. â I shook my head as I exhaled smoke. This old, faintly familiar old man that made me do a double take turns out to be my father. I hadn't seen him since I testified in court against him at eight years old. He had been coked out of his brains, two bottles of shitty Canadian whiskey deep, and when my sister wouldn't stop bothering him for dinner, he hit her. He hit her so hard that her tiny little body spun in a half circle before falling against the glass coffee table. Blunt force trauma. She was dead before I ran into the living room, asking Daddy about the loud noises. He could hardly keep his eyes open, let alone focused on the baseball game that was blaring on the TV. I screamed and cried and tried to wake Ashley up, and all he could manage to do was push me over with his foot as I knelt over my big sister. I ran and called 911 like my grandma had taught me to do, and I told the court the same thing. I hated that they took my daddy away. But I hated him for taking my sister away more. Twenty-one and a half years later, he shows up at my bar. Un-fucking-believable. I heaved the back door open and stepped back inside. I shook my head to clear the cobwebs and memories, and there he was, sitting at my bar, seat sic, drinking a Miller Light and watching Sports Center, like he didn't have a care in the god damn world. How barbaric were those times that wars were fought with men and guns. The battle continued in the night as I carried on with ignoring more helicopters and planes fixed in the sky. I could never see the stars in the city, so their presence never truly bothered me. The latest news broadcasts informed us that the president was weighing his options in declaring war on another nation while asking the citizens to stay focused and refuse to let the war interrupt their work. I moaned about inconvenient another war might be. I suppose I must live with the robots blocking out the sun and stealing my windows for a few more months. ***** More stories at r/Andrew__Wells

I settled in, fighting to keep my confident pose I had entered with. â I'm just going to come out and say it. â Noah seemed to be speaking more to himself than me as he grabbed a wireless keyboard, carefully aiming at the screen as he entered a few rapid keystrokes. The image of the earth became cross sectioned, and what I saw didn't register until Noah spoke again. â The earth isâ¦ pregnant. â I looked at his serious and dour face, then back to the image of something curled up in the inner core of the earth. â Are you fucking with me Noah? â I stood up, annoyed that they would try to pull such a ridiculous prank on someone who was new to the team. â I, heh, really wish that I was. Heh. â A light, accompanied by a buzzer, went off in one corner, cutting Noah's bad attempt at a joke off. â You getting this Noah? â Another person in the room popped their head up from their cubicle, calling to our direction. â Yeah, yeah. â He responded quickly, moving to a desk, summoning data to the screen. â I guess this is scenario delta then! â â I'm sorry, what? â I followed him over, feeling completely out of my league. Prompt: Tell the origin story of the most awesome or most interesting character you can imagine. Story: I don't know who I am.
